column5: b'WHAT AM I DOING IN NEW JERSEY?'
column7: b'In 1975 George Carlin was the first host of this late night comedy show'
column8: b'This word for a food-storage closet comes from a word meaning "bread room"'
column9: b'James Lind\'s 1753 "Treatise On" this vitamin C deficiency suggests eating citrus fruits'
column10: b"How 'bout them football teams of Louisiana Tech & the University of Georgia that both sport this nickname"
column11: b'In 1976 N.J. voted to permit gambling casinos here to raise money for the disabled & elderly; the first opened in 1978'
column12: b'A clovis point is a Native American one'
column13: b"One of Carlin's comic character creations was Al Sleet, a hippie-dippie member of this profession"
column14: b'The French name of this piece of furniture indicates it should be used to store weapons, not clothes & TVs'
column15: b'The diseased lymph gland seen here might tip you to the identity of this colorful 2-word killer of the 14th century'
column16: b'Bill Clinton & Antonin Scalia both graduated from this D.C. university founded in 1789'
column17: b'The state capital was named for a merchant & landowner with this 5-letter name'
column18: b"A devoted follower of Jerry Garcia's band"
column19: b'From 1977 until 2008, George starred in 14 specials on this cable TV network'
column20: b'The first chapter of a C.S. Lewis novel is called "Lucy Looks Into" one of these'
column21: b'This lung disease isolated in 1882 has been found in an ancient mummy, so there should be hieroglyphic Christmas seals'
column22: b'Western hats off to you if you know this Florida university was founded in 1883 in the city of DeLand'
column23: b'In 1879 the first practical incandescent lamp was developed in this community'
column24: b"They call themselves Canada's oldest independent brewery, eh"
column25: b'In the 1960s George appeared with Marlo Thomas on this sitcom'
column26: b'In many preschools, kids keep their things in these cozy "holes"'
column27: b'John Enders was awarded a Nobel Prize for his work on this disease that ends with -myelitis'
column28: b"USC has a satellite campus on this island about 25 miles off L.A.'s coast"
column29: b'In 1910 this ex-Princeton Pres. was elected Governor of N.J. but served only 2 years before taking a new job'
column30: b'A monarch in title who has no real authority'
column31: b'In 2008 at the Kennedy Center, George posthumously received the prize for humor named for this man'
column32: b'This 3-letter word can be a coal scuttle or a trough for carrying bricks'
column33: b'This type of inflammatory bowel disease is named for one of the doctors who wrote about it in 1932'
column34: b'The University of Texas at Austin has erected a statue honoring this founder of the United Farm Workers'
column35: b'In 1994 she became the first woman governor of N.J; she\'d later be in a president\'s cabinet & on "Jeopardy!"'
column36: b'Nickname for a U.S. Marine, perhaps from the shape of his haircut'
column73: b'(Jimmy of the Clue Crew shows a constellation on the monitor.) Look for the Big Dipper to find this third largest constellation: the handle forms its tail; other stars form its paws'
column75: b'In 1581 this world-circumnavigating sailor was made the mayor of Plymouth, England'
column76: b'In his oath one of these pledges that "On my honor I will do my best to do my duty to God & my country"'
column77: b'"If they give you ruled paper, write the other way" is the epigraph to this classic by Ray Bradbury'
column78: b'Ironically, shopping options for women who wear these sizes, French for "small", are shrinking'
column79: b"This hunter constellation is well-armed: he's got a raised club, a shield & a sword dangling from his belt"
column80:
b'"Star Trek III:
The Search For Spock"
(1984)'
column81: b'Tsangyang Gyatso, the sixth man to hold this title, died mysteriously in 1706'
column82: b'The likeness of God used in this 1975 Monty Python comedy is a picture of British cricket star W.G. Grace'
column83: b'"The heart is half a prophet", Philip Roth\'s epigraph to "Goodbye, Columbus", is a proverb from this language'
column84: b'This egg dish that\'s often fat & fluffy has a name derived from a middle French word for "knife blade"'
column85: b'(Kelly of the Clue Crew shows a constellation on the monitor.) Marking its head, Antares is the brightest star in this constellation; the two stars here represent the sting in its tail'
column87: b'This man who lost the 1948 presidential election was referred to as "the little man on the wedding cake"'
column88: b'A deaf student becomes involved with a speech teacher in this Tony-winning play by Mark Medoff'
column89: b'The epigraph of this Willa Cather novel about life on the Nebraska prairies is "Those fields, colored by various grain!"'
column90: b'This collective term for fowl innards often found in gravy is from an Old French word for a game stew'
column91: b'No bull--the Pleiades are found in this constellation of the zodiac'
column93: b'This U.S. mayor who died in 1976 was called the "last of the big-city bosses"'
column94: b'The song "Day By Day" is from this 1970s musical'
column95: b'The 2-word epigraph to his "Howards End": "Only connect"."'
column96: b'The world of high fashion & high society may be called the "beau" this, literally French for "fine world"'
column97: b'(Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a constellation on the monitor.) The constellation Andromeda lies chained to a rock; this hero is next to her in the heavens waiting to rescue her'
column99: b'The topic of the paper he gave to the Manchester Literary & Philosophical Society in 1794 was color blindness'
column100: b'On January 1 in Ancient Rome, citizens gave each other small coins with an image of this god on them'
column101: b'For "The Razor\'s Edge", he chose the apt "The sharp edge of a razor is difficult to pass over"'
column102: b'Antiquers know this French term for "Chinese-style" furniture such as 18th c. Chinese Chippendale'
column134: b"This nickname given a bomber at a 1935 test flight reflected the early belief that it wouldn't need fighter protection"
